abstract.p: Spatially autocorrelated weather and climate may cause population co‐fluctuations over large distances. We show that increasingly frequent rain‐on‐snow (ROS) and icing events in winter synchronize the annual dynamics of Svalbard reindeer populations, while, paradoxically, spatial variation in ROS trends and density‐dependent weather effects cause diverging local population trajectories in the long run. Such decoupling of population dynamics increases species viability under a rapidly warming high‐Arctic climate.
